reasoning: The critique targets an implied practical upshot of the paper—if eutopia is a narrow target, we may need deliberate steering/optimization—and argues that such steering would itself accelerate capabilities/coordination, worsening competitive dynamics and lock-in risks. This bears on how to act on the “no easy eutopia” diagnosis, but it does not directly refute the paper’s main descriptive thesis that near-best futures are a narrow/fragile target across many moral views; the paper also explicitly brackets the ‘will we steer successfully?’ question for the next essay. Hence only moderate centrality. The argument is suggestive but underdeveloped: it assumes that any effective steering must involve building/wielding the strongest optimizer fastest, and that this predictably increases lock-in/expansion, but it doesn’t show that steering can’t be pursued via non-accelerative interventions (e.g., institutional constraints, slower takeoff strategies, differential development of “wisdom” tools) or that the paper’s framing entails pro-capabilities racing. Relevance is high because it engages a cross-tier interaction Forethought cares about (flourishing/trajectory work vs power concentration and lock-in under competitive dynamics), closely connected to several Tier 3 tensions about acceleration vs governance and survival vs flourishing.
title: Optimization for eutopia may itself accelerate existential risk
